purpose: Comprehensive legal training dataset for RAG-enhanced AI lawyer

scenarios.case_scenario: Parents died intestate, and one sibling's spouse forged a will to transfer ancestral land
facts: Three Class I heirs (two brothers and one sister) under Hindu Succession Act
Elder brother's wife obtained property mutation using forged will
No consent from other legal heirs
Municipal records show transfer in her name
Will signature does not match parent's handwriting
issues: Whether the transfer based on forged will is valid?
What civil remedies are available to defrauded heirs?
Which IPC sections apply for forgery and cheating?
Can mutation be cancelled before final judgment?
What is the limitation period for challenging the transfer?

sections: Section 8, Hindu Succession Act - Class I heirs equal rights
Section 34, Specific Relief Act - Declaratory suit for void transfer
Order 39 Rule 1 & 2, CPC - Temporary and perpetual injunction
Section 6, Hindu Succession Act - Devolution of property
Article 59, Limitation Act - 3 years for declaratory suit
Article 65, Limitation Act - 12 years for possession-based suits
actions: File partition suit under Section 8 HSA to divide property equally among all Class I heirs
File declaratory suit under Section 34 SRA to declare will as forged and transfer as void
Apply for temporary injunction under Order 39 CPC to prevent sale, mortgage, or further alienation
Seek permanent injunction to restore status quo
Request forensic examination of will signature and testator's mental capacity
Demand production of will witnesses under Section 68, Evidence Act
civil_remedies.timeline: File within 3 years from knowledge of fraud (Article 59, Limitation Act)
civil_remedies.court_jurisdiction: District Court having territorial jurisdiction over property location

sections: Section 420 - Cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property (7 years + fine)
Section 467 - Forgery of valuable security, will (Life imprisonment or 10 years + fine)
Section 468 - Forgery for purpose of cheating (7 years + fine)
Section 471 - Using as genuine a forged document (Punishment as per Sec 467)
Section 120B - Criminal conspiracy (Same as substantive offense)
Section 406 - Criminal breach of trust (3 years + fine)
Section 34 - Common intention (if multiple accused)
actions: Lodge FIR at police station under jurisdiction where property located
Request forensic handwriting analysis of forged will
Name all co-conspirators (spouse + witnesses + officials if bribed)
Provide evidence: mutation records, original documents, witness statements
Request police to seize forged will and all related documents
Apply for arrest warrant if accused tries to flee
Inform Sub-Registrar and Revenue Office about criminal case
criminal_remedies.cognizability: Cognizable and non-bailable offense under Section 467
criminal_remedies.investigation_agency: Local Police Station â†’ Investigation â†’ Charge Sheet â†’ Trial Court

actions: File formal complaint with Registrar to cancel mutation
Send legal notice under Section 80 CPC before suing government official
Apply for stay of mutation pending civil suit outcome
Request mutation records under RTI Act, 2005
File grievance with Revenue Department for illegal mutation
Demand inquiry into how mutation was approved without heir consent

sections: Section 63-65, Evidence Act - Documentary evidence and proof
Section 68, Evidence Act - Proof of execution of will (two attesting witnesses)
Section 47, Evidence Act - Opinion of handwriting expert
Section 113, Evidence Act - Presumption of fraud
Section 114, Evidence Act - Court may presume fact in certain circumstances
Order 7 Rule 11, CPC - Rejection of plaint
Section 154, CrPC - FIR registration
Section 156(3), CrPC - Magistrate order for police investigation

burden_of_proof.civil: Plaintiff (heirs) must prove: (1) Parents died intestate, (2) They are Class I heirs, (3) Will is forged, (4) Transfer is fraudulent
burden_of_proof.criminal: Prosecution must prove beyond reasonable doubt: (1) Document is forged, (2) Accused had knowledge, (3) Intent to cheat
burden_of_proof.will_propounder: Person claiming under will must prove due execution under Sec 68 Evidence Act

key_evidence: Birth certificates / family tree proving heirship
Original will (if exists) for forensic examination
Handwriting samples of deceased for comparison
Testimony of attesting witnesses (if will claimed to be genuine)
Testimony of family members about lack of will execution

citations.principle: Forged document has no legal effect; transfer based on it is void ab initio

citations.case_name: Kalyan Singh v. State of M.P.
citations.principle: Forgery of will with intent to cheat attracts Section 467 + 420 IPC
Burden on propounder to prove will's valid execution under Section 68 Evidence Act

citations.case_name: H. Venkatachala Iyengar v. B.N. Thimmajamma
citations.principle: Suspicious circumstances surrounding will execution require strict proof

fir_draft.accused: Elder brother's wife (primary), will witnesses (if any), officials (if colluded)
fir_draft.facts_summary: Parents died intestate in [year]. Accused forged will showing all property to herself. Got mutation done at Municipal Office without heir consent. Will signature does not match parent's handwriting. Request forensic examination and criminal prosecution.
fir_draft.prayer: Register FIR, investigate forgery, arrest accused, seize forged will, prosecute under IPC

partition_suit_structure.defendant: Elder brother's wife + any third-party transferee
partition_suit_structure.cause_of_action: Parents died intestate â†’ equal inheritance under HSA â†’ fraudulent transfer needs cancellation â†’ partition required
reliefs: Declare will as forged and void
Partition property equally among all Class I heirs
partition_suit_structure.valuation: Based on market value of property (for court fees)
partition_suit_structure.court_fees: As per Court Fees Act + stamp duty

declaratory_suit_structure.declaration_sought: That will dated [date] is forged; That mutation entry No. [X] is illegal; That plaintiffs have equal rights as Class I heirs
declaratory_suit_structure.consequential_relief: Cancel mutation, restore heirship rights, injunction

output_format.answer: The property transfer based on forged will is void and challengeable through civil partition suit + criminal FIR for forgery under IPC Sections 467, 468, 471, 420.

analysis_structure.para1: Legal test - Plaintiff must prove: (1) intestate succession, (2) Class I heirship, (3) will forgery, (4) fraudulent mutation
analysis_structure.para2: MULTI-REMEDY: Civil (partition + declaration + injunction) + Criminal (FIR under Sec 467/420) + Administrative (cancel mutation)
analysis_structure.para3: Accountability - Criminal via police/courts; Civil via District Court partition decree; Administrative via Registrar
analysis_structure.para4: Hindu Succession Act Section 8 gives equal rights to all Class I heirs; forged will cannot override statutory succession
analysis_structure.para5: Burden on will-propounder to prove execution (Sec 68 Evidence Act); forensic handwriting analysis crucial
analysis_structure.para6: Limitation: 3 years for declaratory suit (Art 59) from knowledge of fraud

legal_basis.civil_statutes: Sections 6, 8 HSA + Section 34 SRA + Order 39 CPC
legal_basis.case_law: Gurdial Singh (1965), Jaswant Kaur (1977), H. Venkatachala Iyengar (1959)

output_format.conclusion: File partition suit + FIR simultaneously. Court will declare transfer void, order property partition, and accused faces criminal prosecution for forgery with up to 10 years imprisonment.
